Feedback on our existing tech blog.

* Disclaimer - i’m not saying i’m right here, but the conversation needs to start

TL;DR

Recommendations (in no particular order):

  • Define our target audiences
  • Define some subject matter guidelines
  • Tailor the post classification to the newly defined audiences
  • Offer incentives to write posts
  • Hire a technical writer to proof and edit all posts
  • Re-skin

Target audience

There is no consistent target audience across posts. After going over the posts, I discern the following disparate audiences:

  1. Marketing
  2. Internal
  3. Specialized
  4. Developer
  5. Existing Customer
  6. No idea

There are a couple ways that I can think of to address this:

  1. Have more than one blog. At the very least internal and external.
  2. Pick a target and delete the irrelevant posts
  3. Clearly classify (tag?) by audience and default to something relevant to whomever we define as our primary target

To be relevant to the Ruby community, the target audience needs to be entry-level to senior-level Rubyists (I don’t think we really have the fire-power to target the cutting-edge crowd, yet).

Design

The current design is out-dated, uninviting, and difficult to scan and read. There are glaring design and typography anti-patterns that I can enumerate if need be. It is scheduled for an overhaul to match the marketing blog (i think), however even our marketing blog has much room for improvement. Here is a beautiful blog: html5rocks.com. Being that our business is helping people develop their online-presence, it would seem reasonable to have a higher bar for public-facing sites. We could/should to be winning awards for this stuff, as opposed to being passable.

I ported one of our existing posts over to this layout for a side-by-side:

old: Using CORS for Cross-Domain Ajax Requests

new: CORS for X-Domain Ajax

Content

People come back to a blog because they expect more of whatever they liked in the first place. We need some common thread, weather it is target-audience, writing style, subject-matter, or other. We currently do not have consistency in any of the above.
